awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Collaborative Research: The Integrity of Mail Voting
awd_abstract_narration:
Given the increase use of vote by mail (VBM) due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the investigators focus on mail-in voters' experience with how they seek, obtain, complete, return and have their mail ballots counted. They examine citizens' perceptions about the integrity of elections using VBM by assessing concerns about variation in the institutional structures of VBM, the secrecy of VBM the process, and the coercion that VBM voters may face from their peer group. The investigators use a state-centric survey design that includes an oversample in 10 states that have a mixture of VBM systems. The oversample is important and gives additional statistical power and leverage about state election administration and laws. 

The sample consist of only registered voters who report voting by mail in the 2020 election. Surveys are solicited online using Qualtrics software. E-mail addresses for registered voters by state will be purchased from L2. The investigators completed 200 online surveys with mail voters in 40 states, and 1,000 with mail voters in 10 states, along with 100 in-person voters in each these states, for a total sample of 23,000. This research provides a baseline for concerns about voter integrity related to mail balloting. Furthermore, it establishes whether alternative mail voting systems differ in terms of when, where, and with whom mail ballots are completed and returned. This project should inform scholars and policy makers in several areas of VBM policy administration. Findings from the study are also valuable in increasing public confidence in VBM election procedures. The research involves undergraduate researchers at all three campuses of the collaborative study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As a result of the COVID-19 virus, many states both adopted and expanded opportunities for voters to cast their ballot by mail during the 2020 election-cycle. Approximately 75% of all voters in the 2020 Presidential election were eligible to submit their ballot using some form of mail voting. In fact, 46% of all votes were cast via mail in 2020.

Even before the election, critics of mail voting identified a number of shortcomings with this mode that could impact the integrity (validity/eligibility) of ballots cast, raising the specter of potential voter fraud. Others highlighted the potential lack of secrecy related to a voter’s choices using this form of voting, which could accentuate coercion on the part of others.

As we now know, these types of accusations were greatly amplified following the election, especially from then President Trump. This rhetoric helped to undermine some voters’ confidence in the outcome of the presidential election, especially in states where the outcome was close.

Prior academic research in this area could be generally characterized by an absence of reliable and independent measures concerning voters’ perceptions of the integrity of mail voting. To alleviate this knowledge gap and determine if such concerns about the integrity of mail balloting are valid, we carried out a large-scale, nationally representative survey of voters following the 2020 election. In all, we obtained over 19,000 completed surveys from voters across the United States, with approximately half of that number being absentee-by-mail voters.

Through our detailed survey instrument, we were able to collect a wide variety of information concerning voters’ experiences casting a ballot in the 2020 election, including their overall evaluations of the process. We also collected measures related to voter perceptions of confidence in the electoral process at various levels, including individual, county, state, and national. Additionally, we probed voters about their assessments concerning the secrecy of their ballot, both from a governmental/administrative standpoint, as well as withing their own social network of family, friends, and co-workers.  

To date, we can report findings from this research project in a number of areas. First, we created a profile of who voted by mail in the 2020 presidential election, the reasons they did so, and how these voters evaluated the overall process. In general, fear of COVID-19 was positively associated with the usage of mail voting, although rates did vary by presidential vote choice with Trump supporters less likely to have relied on this form of voting. In terms of voter confidence, vote-by-mail actually scored higher than early in-person or election-day precinct voting. Again, evaluations were colored through the lens of partisan perceptions as Trump voters demonstrated lower confidence levels for vote-by-mail. In the absence of a pandemic, the future of vote-by-mail utilization levels would appear to hinge on a number of factors, including partisan perceptions of the process and the ease of the voting process within the state in question.

Second, we also have findings to report related to the issue of ballot secrecy. Previous research indicates that a substantial portion of the electorate does not believe their ballot is secret, and a majority of voters freely share their vote choices with others. We demonstrate that similar dimensions of ballot secrecy exist across time through our analysis of the 2020 electorate. Although levels of psychological and social secrecy remain generally comparable over recent history, our findings do diverge from those of previous research in terms of which groups are more likely to exhibit higher levels of insecurity as related to ballot secrecy. Chief among these is the partisan divisions that came to the forefront in the 2020 election, with Republicans and Democrats now significantly different in regard to their levels of psychological and social secrecy. More specifically, we find 2020 voters, especially Republicans, have grown even more insecure about the secrecy of their ballot and less inquisitive about others’ vote choices. We also find in 2020 that voting method (in-person or by-mail) is linked to at least one dimension of ballot secrecy, whereas previously voting method was wholly unrelated to this concept. In-person voters (both early and election-day) were more likely to believe their votes were not administratively secure, as compared to those who cast a ballot by mail. Our findings also demonstrate that voters who are in the political minority at the local-level are less confident about the secrecy of their ballot, compared with those whose vote choices match the political majority.

While these two sets of findings examine different aspects of the voting process, they are commonly linked in 2020 by the presence of political polarization within the electorate. As with many other political events, the perceptions of voting in general, and of absentee-by-mail voting in particular, are without a doubt viewed through the partisan lens of the voter in question.
